text:
I made this recipe AS IS before I made any changes and it was hands down the best chili recipe I have made!! next time though, I put my own little spin on it and I think it elevated it to another level! The recipe as is has a thinner consistency and isn't overly spicy. I added up to 1/2 tsp of cayenne to make it spicier, but what make it out of this world was 1/4 cup corn meal!!! Made it thick like chili you would get in a restaurant. This recipe makes a lot so you can freeze half if need be and is absolutely delicious!!!

text:
I could eat this chili until my stomach bursts!  All the ingredients are in the right proportion; I wouldn't suggest altering a single thing.  Take it to a pot-luck and I guarantee that people will gobble it up.  I like things hot, and I would consider this chili to be about a 5/10 on my scale.  It'll clear your sinuses, but you won't be gulping down milk to cool your tongue!  This recipe heats up well in the microwave, and freezes just fine - we've got three meal's worth in the deep freeze right now.  By all means, give this chili recipe a try, I'm sure you'll like it.

text:
I probably shouldn't rate this recipe because I made so many changes, but it is a great base recipe to tweak to your own liking.  The end result was the best chili I have ever made!!  I used 1 lb ground beef and 1 lb sausage to give a little more depth to the flavor.  I also followed the advice of others and substituted the tomato juice with tomato sauce and the tomato sauce with diced tomatoes.  I didn't realize that I was almost out of chili powder until I had already started the chili, so I only used about 1 T and added hot sauce (tobasco) in place of the rest of the chili powder.  I used one can of chili beans (with liquid) and one can kidney beans (rinsed).  I followed the rest of the seasonings.  It only took about 15 minutes to put together, then I let it simmer for about 2 hours.  Served with sour cream, cheese, fresh chopped tomatoes and corn chips.  I will make this recipe over and over again.  I have never received so many compliments - on anything I have ever made!!

text:
I won the chili cook-off with this recipe last night. Everyone commented that they liked the combination of spicy and sweet. I adjusted the ingredients to feed 15 people. I also  followed the first couple of reviews and substituted tomato juice for paste, and diced tomatos for juice. FYI, for 15 people, I used 2, 28oz cans of diced tomato, and 2, 29oz cans of tomato sauce. It's a bit thick till it cooks down. Enjoy!!

text:
If I could rate this chili more than 5 stars I would! 5 stars for easy! 5 stars for delicious! I have been making this for over a year and I have tried it different ways. Now I use crushed tomatoes instead of tomato juice, and diced tomatoes with diced green chilies in place of tomato sauce. I use 1 can of kidney beans, one of pinto and one of black (all rinsed) in leiu of one of the lbs of beef, thus cutting down on the sat. fat and red meat content. Doubled the cumin because I like the smokiness. I also added one hot jalepeno without the seeds, diced, or cayenne pepper. I throw it all in the crockpot and let it cook for about 4 hours. SPECTACULAR!

text:
Yummy! 'Nuf said!  I noticed many reviews commented that this recipe is somewhat bland.  I would encourage everyone to double check the age of the spices they're using.  If they're over a year old, you probably need to pump it up a little as spices lose their punch as they age.  I recently noticed a jar of chili powder at my mother's that was probably at least 10 years old.  She didn't see the problem with that.  The problem with that is that she's basically adding slightly flavored dust to her recipes...yuk!  I used fresh spices for this chili and it turned out perfectly tasty and spicy.

Update:  I've been making this recipe consistently for a few years now, and I've found that I'm happiest when I double the beans (Sorry, serious chili lovers), and increase the amount of all the vegetables, plus add 1/4 cup corn meal to thicken it up.  Nevertheless, this recipe is a great starting point that is easy to tweak to your satisfaction.

None
text:
This definitely is a keeper! Loved it! Here's one thing you can do with this recipe (or any soup recipe that has beans in it) to make it thicker if you just love the taste and don't want to use flour, cornstarch, cornmeal, etc. to thicken it - Put some of the beans in a blender with some of the juice from whatever recipe you are using and puree. Add this to your recipe and you won't really change the taste of the recipe but it will make the broth thicker. If you want to: you can add a few more beans or less beans to make your recipe turn out the way you like.

text:
I helped my eldest son make this only slightly--he did most of the work himself. We did not add the celery, we used two large red peppers, we used "a mess" of fresh minced garlic instead of garlic powder and we added one 4 oz. can of mild diced green chilies. We also used black beans because that was all we had in the pantry. After the meat was browned, he threw everything in the crockpot and let it go all day. Very good! We all thought this was one of the better chili recipes we've ever had. I was quite proud of him. This will be his go-to chili recipe from now on.

text:
I needed an amazing chili recipe for a family gathering, and I knew that over a thousand reviews couldn't be wrong.  I followed the recipe closely and added only a small can of diced jalapenos for a touch of heat.  The chili was a big hit!  It was just spicy enough for everyone to enjoy without having to gulp down cold drinks to cool the tastebuds.  I received lots of compliments, which was especially nice because I rarely make chili from scratch.  I made it a day ahead in order to allow the flavors to blend and heated it in a crockpot for the party.  Several guests used the chili to top baked potatoes.  I'll definitely save this recipe for future gatherings!

text:
This is the best basic chili recipe! I changed quite a few things but I know it would have been great without any changes.
I used I 29oz can tomato sauce, 28 oz can of diced tomatoes (with liquid), and a 10oz can of tomato soup. I didnt add the sugar because the condensed campbell soup is already sweet. I did this because I like my chili really thick so I emitted all that juice. The only other thing I changed was 3lbs beef and an extra tsp of cumin to compensate. Everything else was done just like the original recipe......turned out awesome!
I just made this for the second time and have to say, the can of tomato soup makes all the difference for me....dont know why but its a must!

text:
Are you kidding me?! How can something so simple taste so wonderful? This was hands down the best chili I've ever made. Because of the ingredients on hand, I cut the recipe in half (just me and my hubby eating) and used 2 quarts of homemade canned tomatoes w/onion & green pepper in place of the tomato juice & tomatoe sauce. I ran my hand blender through the tomatoes before adding to the pot because I like them chopped up small. I added a pat of butter and topped with Oyster crackers. Oh, my gosh it was great last night when I made it, but it's even better today for lunch! Do yourself (and your family) a favor and try this one today!

text:
Made some changes based on other reviews - I used 1 lb beef, 1 lb mild italian sausage.  I used 2 cans of diced petite tomatoes and 2 cans of tomato sauce.  I used one can dark Kidney beans and 1 can chili beans w/ medium sauce.  Drained/rinsed kidney beans but adding the sauce from the chili beans.  I dbled all spices, cooked meat in Worchestir sauce, used only a 1/2 cup of onion (not huge onion fans), 1 green pepper cut into md chunks, no celery (husband doesn't like it)  I cooked the meat, spices, onion and green peper in the skillet, then combined it w/ the sauce and beans.  Cooked for 3 hrs on high, then 2 hours on low in the crockpot.
half hour before it was done, I added a 1/4 cup of cornstarch since it was a little watery to my liking - next time I will drain the diced tomatoes so it won't be so watery.
Brought to friends house for dinner and everyone loved it.  Husband said it was the best chili I've made yet.  Hostess said it was just the right amt of heat for her.  
i was running late so whipped this up and into the crock pot in only 20 min - super easy to make.

I've made this twice now and I think it's going to be my new standby. I noticed a lot of folks didn't use quite the same volume of juice that the recipe calls for, but I used V8 juice for the tomato juice. Cornbread on the side makes for one delicious meal.

text:
This is the best basic chili recipe I have ever used.  You can make it to suit what you have on hand and add to it for bigger crowds.  I usually vary the tomatoes with what I have in the pantry using whole, diced or stewed and sauce.  I also use more beans than called for to stretch it for a crowd.  I use 1 lb ground beef and 1 lb ground turkey to make it slightly healthier.  This is not a spicy chili but I keep a bottle of tabasco out with the toppings for folks to make it to thier liking.  Overall, its the BEST!!!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This is the best chili ever! It has the perfect amount of flavor and takes out the guess work. I made it for the super bowl and everyone loved it. My friend is convinced we should enter our town chili cook off with this recipe and based on other reviews I think we would win. I did change the recipe a little based on my own liking and on some of the reviews I read. I used 1 lb. of ground beef and 1 lb. of ground sausage. I like chunky tomato's in my chili so I replaced 1 (46 fluid ounce can of tomato juice) w/ 28 oz. can diced tomatoes and 18 oz vegetable juice. I used a 1/4 teaspoon of ground cayenne instead of 1/8 teaspoon. Lastly I added 1/4 cup cornmeal. This one is a keeper for me. Thank you for a great recipe!

text:
Living in Belgium, I had to make one tweak to the recipe. After the ground beef finished browning, I drained it, then added 3/4 of a bottle (about 8 oz) of beer. I let that come to a boil for a bit, then put that concoction into the kettle and added the other ingredients as directed. I used a blonde beer, but next time I will use a darker beer (whatever you use, make sure it's 'quality' beer). Either way, I think that gives this excellent chili recipe an extra layer of flavor.

text:
Fabulous!  I have made approx 8 times.  Only mods that I have made is to add a can of diced tom's, and more vegetables.  If you allow it to simmer for approx 3 hours, then the excess liquid from the tom juice reduces which makes the ingredients "get happy".  Heat level is perfect for us, but some may need to kick it up.  We top with fresh diced tom's, corn chips, sour cream, and cheddar cheese.  Super recipe!

text:
This is amazing!!! I love chili and wanted to finally make my own. In search of chili recipes and reading over many of them, this recipe caught my eye and I thought to give it a try...thank goodness I did. My husband is not a big fan of chili and he was loving every taste. I mostly used the ingredients as stated, but I did do a few modifications. Instead of Tomato juice, I substituted it with tomato sauce and subbed the tomato sauce with diced tomatoes. I used kidney beans and red beans (next time I will try a mix with black beans). I added 1/4 cup of cornmeal as suggested by a previous reviewer because I love thick chili. Also, I added 4 pieces of cooked bacon (which I cooked in the skillet and once it was done, I added the bacon grease to the ground beef while I was browning the meat) and a tablespoon of Jack Daniel's BBQ sauce. This was a wonderful recipe and I can't wait to make this again for my family and friends.

text:
I loved this chili recipe.  It is easy and very flavorful.  The only modification I made to this was that I used fresh garlic (about 6-7 cloves), ground red pepper instead of cayenne, and I added 1 chopped serrano chile pepper.  It was fantastic.  For those who said the chili was too liquidy, if you let it cook down for about 2 hours, some of the water will evaporate off giving a thicker chili.

Great chili recipe. It's very similar to the oe I grew up eating. I skipped the green peppers & celery. I added diced tomatoes. I also replaced the other can of beans with green beans- just because I usually do and I really like them.

As a lover of chili, I have to say that this is a GREAT recipe!  It was easy and quick to put together. The flavors were clasic chili all the way. Unfortunately, my family is scolfield (sp?) handicapped and I was forced to cut back on the chili powder. For all you chili lovers out there, stop searching and fire up the stove!

AEEVR

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this several times and, accordingly, it has evolved. For one, when you make any sort of stew/curry, you should sweat the veggies with salt (get all the water out). Mix the dry seasonings with the meat and add  to the sweated veggies over high heat until the meat gets nice and browned. Again, this means getting the water out and you should start to get some brown bits sticking to the pan. This condenses the flavors and the direct heat on the spices bring out their oils, intensifying their flavors. Then add your wet ingredients scraping up those browned bits from the side of the pan. I never discard fat. That's just throwing away flavor.  Tonight, I will add chopped fresh oregano and fresh garlic before serving to give it a little zing.

Things I add: tbsp cocoa powder, pinch of cloves, smoked paprika.
Things I sub: ground pork or chorizo for part of the ground beef, pasilla or anaheim chiles for bell pepper, beer for tomato juice, diced tomatoes instead of sauce.

I only give it 4 stars but with the changes I made, it would be 5: tomato sauce sub for juice and canned diced tomatoes subd for the sauce, half of the meat sausage, and I only used abt2 Tbls of chili powder instead of the 1/4 cup cuz I have young kids and we do not enjoy the spiciness. I can't imagine how hot it would be with the whole  1/4 cup! Also, I didn't have cayene pepper, so I added 1/4 tsp Tobasco and added a couple of Tablespoons of cornmeal to thicken as another reviewer suggested. It did turn out delicious and there was enough (without doubling) for 2 families. Will definitely use this recipe from now on.

text:
I've been using this recipe for some time now and it is always a hit. I've given the recipe to several people who always say it's the best chili they've had.  I did make some changes, some minor, some major that make it even more amazing than it already is:
I put half ground beef, half hot italian sausage
I use canned tomatoes with juice in place of the tomatoe juice because I like the chunks of tomato.  
Other than that I make it as is...sometimes I half the amount of cayenne pepper for myself because I find it a little spicy but 90% of the people who have had it say the spice is perfect.  Great recipe

This is a great recipe! I adjusted it for 15 people and only substituted 3 crushed garlic cloves for the powder. Also the vegetables and garlic were sauteed with the meat. Everything was put in a crockpot and cooked on low for 9 hours. I think the tomato juice was what made it so good. I did not add anything to thicken it. I will definitely make this again!



Made this again with ingredients for 15 but kept tomato juice at original recipe proportion. It was even better this time around. Don't change a thing!

text:
Family loved it and not too spicy - just enough kick. My teenaged daughter even asked me to pack it for her  lunch the next day. Liked the simplicity of recipe that besides cooking beef, all other ingredients thrown in together at the same time to cook. Made it exactly as is - other then cooked on medium heat for half hour with pot uncovered to thicken it. Just FYI, leave the tomato juice - don't substitute. It has a very high vitamin C content - another great way to sneak vitamins in your family's food!

text:
I stuck this in my recipe box last year and finally got around to making this. With the suggestion from Debi P. to exchange the tomato juice for sauce and sauce for diced tomatoes, this turned out EXCELLENT! I added a 1/2 teaspoon of cajun seasoning to the mix, cooked the beef with Italian seasoning, and used B&M Kidney Beans instead of the red beans. I put this in the crock pot instead of a kettle, let it cook on high for 3 hours, then on low for another hour. Since the kiddo can't eat hot stuff, we waited until we plated our bowls to add Tabasco sauce. A little sour cream, and voila! Dinner is served. Easy peasy. And lots of leftovers!

text:
After reading the recipe and several reviews, I tried it with a few suggested tweeks -- what a hit! I've made it several times and my family and friends have all declared this to be their favorite chile ever, with just the right blend of flavors and texture. I used a 28 oz. can diced tomatoes, a can of tomato soup and a 15 oz. can tomato sauce for the liquids, left out the cumin, but kept everything else as stated. It freezes well (when I was able to make it and put it up without family knowing). I look forward to this go-to dish during the cold winter nights ahead. Thanks!

text:
This chili is awesome. I will admit I didn't do it quite as described but it was so good I have to give the original 5 stars. I used 3 pounds lean ground beef, a large can of tomato sauce, a large can of Rotel, no onions/celery/peppers, and I used a can each of black beans, dark red kidney beans, and pinto beans. Also browned the meat and then threw it all in the slow cooker on low for 6 hours. It was so good I've made it twice in two weeks and each time my guests raved about it. It's perfect with or without small Frito chips, shredded cheddar cheese and even sour cream. Love it!

I kind of winged it at the store before even looking for a chili recipe so i didn't have the celery or tomato juice for this recipe. I simply left the celery out and substituted two 10 oz cans of tomatoes with chilis with the juice along with the other ingredients that I did have. This was an easy recipe to follow and the results were great. I am not a fan of chili but my husband likes it and i was glad to have this to make for him before he heads to work on a cold and wet night. I had a huge bowl myself and will probably have seconds. I garnished the chili with sour cream, shredded cheddar cheese and chopped green onions.

dateLastModified:

userID:
2007528
Display Name:
Goldana
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

0
madeRecipesCount:
45
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/32932.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good base for a Chili recipe, but you need to add your own touches or it doesn't have that kick to it. 
I skipped the tomato juice and used two cans of plain tomato sauce. I found that the vegetable ratio was way too low. If you cut the recipe in half, it calls for only 2 tablespoons of green pepper for a serving size of 5! That is not nearly enough to get the taste and texture of the peppers in the Chili. 
I think I easily quadrupled the celery, peppers, and onion. I chopped up 3 different colors of peppers (red, yellow, and green) to add a nice visual appeal. 
I used fresh chopped garlic, instead of powder. I also added a few tablespoons of Worcestershire sauce and a bouillon cube. I added more of the hot spices to it as well because it was just too bland as is. 
I served it with white rolls on the side and sour cream to put on top. With the additional changes it was easily a 4-5 star Chili. The recipe as written though is simply average. People who do not like a lot of spice might find it perfectly fine. I needed to give it quite a kick to make it work for me though. 
I will definitely make it again with my own additions of course. Thanks for the recipe George!

text:
This was excellent.  I had to alter it slightly when I realized I didn't have any cayenne, but it was good.  I used a whole 64 oz bottle of tomato juice (that's what it came in and we don't drink tomato juice straight).  Also omited the cayenne (just didn't have any), and eyeballed the green pepper and probably ended up with 1/2 a cup.  Also took another reviewer's advice and added about 1/3 cup of cornmeal towards the end to thicken - that was AWESOME!  but be careful to add that very slowly, otherwise it clumps.  This is a big time keeper.

text:
I love this recipe!  Everyone who has tried my chili raved about how good it is.  The only thing I change is that I use diced tomatoes instead of tomato juice because I prefer it a bit chunky..I use the same amount of diced tomatos as I do sauce (so, for 10 servings, I use 29-30 oz of diced tomatoes and sauce each).  It's so good and I find it to be pretty healthy too.  I usually make a huge pot and it lasts us several days.

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
4426232
Display Name:
BQRC
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
7
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We printed this recipe over a year ago, and have used it about a dozen times since then- it's become our standard chili recipe.    Based on other reviews, we swapped 46ozs of tomato sauce for the tomato juice and 29oz of crushed tomato for tomato sauce.  We also prefer the taste of fresh garlic to garlic powder, so we mince up a couple of cloves.  We do not find the sugar necessary, but that probably depends on how sweet or bitter your particular batch of tomatoes is.  I'd add that at the end, if necessary at all.    The chili made this way has a great texture and spice balance.  It's got a ton of flavor, but isn't too spicy.  If we're cooking for ourselves, we double the cayenne.  I love that the heat is one of the flavors, but does not overpower the other seasonings- great balance.    When making this recipe for a crowd (which I highly suggest) we kept it warm in a crock pot on our buffet.  Worked out very well.  As other reviewers mentioned, this also freezes beautifully!
Review:

text:
I love my own chili recipe but desperately needed to cut off my McCormick's Chili seasoning "addiction".  It was getting too expensive & was tasting too salty lately.  Anyway, I just needed to find a chili seasoning recipe and this was perfect.  I didn't follow the rest of the recipe; however, I'm giving this 5 stars because it served my purpose of replacing the McCormicks.  For my own chili recipe, I use both diced and stewed tomatoes; brown sugar vs. white sugar; a touch of cinnamon; roasted jalapeno peppers and finish it off with crushed Fritos and cheese.

text:
I think this is more of a 4 1/2 recipe, but I made a few changes so can't vouch for the original. The changes I made were partly out of necessity, part based on other reviews, and part just cuz. I don't know exactly how much beef I used, but I'm guessing between 2 1/2 and 3 lbs (I had bought a 5 lbs roll, and it was what was left) I couldn't find plain red beans, so I bought a 2lb can of chili beans, and just added them all in, didn't think to drain and rinse em. I also didn't bother to measure the green pepper, just used a whole one. I used an whole onion and 1/2 onion, cuz I had a half onion in the fridge I wanted used up, and the whole onion measured up a tad bit short. And, I added an extra tsp cumin, doubled to oregano, sugar and cayenne. Also, since my husband ended up working late, the chili ended up simmering closer to 3 hours. This didn't hurt it a bit. Usually when my husband comes in late, he's to tired to eat much, but he downed 2 big bowls and actually wants the left overs for dinner tonight. I few reviews mentioned that it was thin and watery, I didn't have that problem, but it maybe because I tossed in a few extra solids. T. It's not a hot chili, but does have plenty of flavor, which is how I like it but the chili powder still kinda overwhelms everything a bit for my taste, so next time I make it, I'll probably scale it down just a teeny bit.

text:
Wow! I am not usually a big chili fan, but this is GREAT chili. I think this would win awards. The only differences in my version were:

I used a food processor to chop the onion and the celery b/c my kids wont eat chunks of onions in anything. 

I omitted the green pepper only b/c I didnt have any.

I didnt realize Iw as low on chili pepper - I only had about 1/8 cup instead of 1/4 cup and was afraid this would ruin the chili, but it didnt. NExt time I'll use the whole 1/4 cup but really, 1/8 was fine!

Oh, and I used ground turkey b/c we dont eat a lot of red meat. 

GREAT chili. Thanks for posting!!!

text:
I didn't have tomato juice on hand, so I replaced the sauce and juice with the equivalent amount of stewed tomatoes and their juice. My husband loves onions and cumin, so I nearly doubled both. I fried the onions in with the ground beef so they would be carmelized and yummy. Instead of plain red beans, I used 2 cans of chili-style beans with their sauce. I also replaced the white sugar with a sprinkling of brown. This all made for a rich, super-flavorful, stick-to-your-ribs chili that my husband and daughter really loved! Yum!

text:
I tweaked this recipe just slightly by adding more beans, cutting the chili powder & cumin both in half, and it was the best chili my husband & I have ever had!  I cut the recipe in half (5 servings), followed everything except I omitted the celery and added 2 cans (15oz) of  drained & rinsed beans (instead of the 1 cup suggested), used 1 TB chili powder and 1/2 tsp cumin - I kept all other spices at the recipe amounts suggested.  I mixed all of the spices in one bowl and then added the spice to the chili.  My husband is very picky about what he eats, but this was so tasty, wasn't "soupy" and we both loved it!  Will definitely make again.

text:
I like this recipe a lot!  I've made it every week since the first time I've tried it, and I've gotten compliments from my family and coworkers.  The only changes I did were to add more celery and green pepper than what the recipe calls for and I also added about 1/2 a teaspoon of cayenne pepper instead of 1/4 teaspoon.  I used kidney beans instead of red beans (it was what I had in the cupboard) and those worked well too.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
True story-- I live in Texas, have several times made this chili totally vegan, entered it in "regular" ("carnivore") chili competitions, and taken home ribbons, including 1st place.  I used Boca crumbles once (browned in olive oil first to add that greasy chili component) and cheap TVP the next, so zero cholesterol or animal protein in it so we can avoid the diabetes and heart disease so common in our meat-obsessed society now.   Everywhere I take this, people rave, and nobody believes it's all vegan.  I wait till I got the ribbon before telling everyone there wasn't a spec of meat in it.  It's cooking up in the slow cooker right now, and I'm going to wow more people tomorrow at my new job.  I, like other users, also changed the tomato juice to tomato sauce, and the tomato sauce to diced tomatoes.  Other than that, and getting rid of the animal flesh for stuff that lets me eat till I almost burst without gaining an ounce, the recipe is perfect as is.

text:
This is my first time making chili with a recipe.   Usually I cook and taste and add as I go.   I put my trust in the author and I wasn't disappointed.   The only place I didn't follow the recipe is with the green peppers.   I didn't have any to put in.  From past experience, I would have loved them in here.   I would probably compare this to a pretty good restaurant chili with some heat, but not a lot.   I've also never made chili before without some tomatoes in it.   I will probably use this again when I'm serving for those afraid of the tomato monster.

I also do one can of black beans and two cans of chili beans and a little finely diced jalapenos.  Really good chili recipe for a grandma who has never been able to make chili from scratch.

This is a great chili...I made this a couple months ago, and froze half to have later.  I thawed in in the fridge overnight and it made a fantastic quick winter meal.  I like to top this with a pile of grated mild cheddar and some sour cream, and serve with some buttered rolls.  My husband is picky about his chili, and he enjoyed this.  It's nice and thick, heavy on the meat, and just enough kick for both of us.  Will definitely make again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Hubby asked for the canned "Hormel Chili w/out beans" to add to baked potatoes tonight.  Because I'm trying to cook more naturally, I searched allrecipes for a good homemade chili recipe instead.    I made this recipe without the beans and used can of chunky tomato sauce in place of juice (as others suggested).  I accidentally bought a "chili powder blend" instead of plain chili powder.   It has cocoa powder, cinnamon, cloves, red chili powder and more.  I found that even with all those flavors the chili was a bit bland.  I doubled the seasonings, added more salt and it was much better.  Hubby still likes the Hormel better, unfortunately, due to the lack of chunky veggies in Hormel.  I loved it and it tastes AWESOME on my baked potato.

text:
We love this chili - I've made it several times.  It's good with the tomato juice but I only use 1/2 the amount b/c it thins the chili too much and takes away from the flavor of the spices.  I often make it w/o the juice and substitute 2 cans diced tomatoes undrained.  I always add some diced tomatoes regardless and an extra can of beans (usually black).  We always freeze the leftover and it's just as good the 2nd time around!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe a couple of times now, and both times were excellent.  I mainly use it for the spice combo, which is great.  In the past I used the chili seasoning packets, but have been trying cook healthier, with less sodium.  Instead of tomato juice and sauce, I use tomato sauce and crushed tomatoes.  I used to use sause and diced, but have found that the 'crushed with added puree' version provides a better texture. (Diced doesn't always cook down to the consistency I want.)  When possible, I make my soups on the stove, and let them simmer on low for several hours, then freeze any leftovers.  I found this recipe works excellent for freezing.  I save the little plastic trays from frozen entrees (eq. to one reg. size bowl), freeze chili, soup, etc, in them, then pop them out and store in foodsaver bags.  We call them chili pucks, or soup cicles, and they keep for months!

text:
Great ingredients make a great recipe. The spice mixture is perfect and the next time I make it I will add two cans of diced tomatoes to sub for the juice. We like a thick chili so will cut back on the sauce/juice addition for our preference. I fried the beef in a skillet and then threw all in the crockpot to simmer for 3 hours on high. I also made with cooked up dry kidney beans. Lastly for more heat I threw in a whole hot pepper and pulled it out before serving. Thanks for the recipe! Oh yeah, I served w/ sourdough grilled cheese sandwiches. Yummy!

Delicious!  My husband and I do not care for really spicy chili and this recipe had just the right amount of spice for us.  Using what I had in my pantry I had to make a couple changes.  I substituted one quart of home canned tomatoes for the tomato juice and used only one 15-oz. can of tomato sauce and one 15-oz. can of black beans (all I had).  My husband doesnt like onions and peppers so I had to leave those out, however I did use onion powder.  I am sure they would have been delicious.  Even with the substitutions, the chili was wonderful!

I can't even believe how good this chili is! I would give it more than 5 stars if I could. It isn't even done cooking, but I already know. My husband couldn't wait for it to finish before he got himself a bowl. I tried to get him to wait, but he wouldn't. He LOVES chili and he says this is just perfect! I left out the bell peppers and celery just according to our own taste and added 1/4 tsp. of cayenne pepper because we like things spicy. I took another reviewers advice and added a little less than 1/4 c. of corn meal. This is so good I know I will be cooking this frequently and I'm glad because I can't wait to eat a lot of this! It was my first time making chili from scratch and I'm so glad it came out well. It is fast, easy and affordable! THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU!!!!

text:
fantastic. I had to make a few changes but nothing major. I like a thicker chili so instead of tomato juice I used a large can of crushed tomatoes, a 15 ounce can of stewed tomatoes, a little can of tomato sauce and a 15 oz can of tomato paste. I also used 3 different kinds of beans. I used the same spices except I didn't have any cayenne so I used habanero sauce instead. We like things hot so I threw in some diced jalapenos too. To give a little more flavor to the meat itself I browned it with some of the onion and a clove of minced garlic. Great recipe. I don't think I changed things that really impact the recipe itself except the hotness. It's a good combination of spices. good flavor.

city:

country:
None
text:
Great recipe and I would recommend this for anyone looking for a nice Yankee chili.  As a side note, I'd like to respond to those who criticize others here for putting their own twists on submitted recipes.  I just don't understand why some think its a sin not to follow a recipe "exactly".  I think any recipe on here should be experimented with.  I for one, LOVE that others have tried different ingredients, cooking methods or whatever.. it gives me great ideas and helps me to be more creative when I cook.  There are few professional chef's here and I think any recipe posted to a public forum is open to new ideas and fun surprises.  I have a recipe posted here and nothing gives me more pleasure than to see people giving it a try - changing up the methods, adjusting the baking time, adding sesame seeds to the top.. whatever.  I find it exciting and extremely flattering that they would try my recipe in the first place.  If they change half the ingredients and the recipe fails, then I suspect people in here are intelligent enough to figure out the source of the failure.  There is only one ingredient substitution that drives me nuts.. diet or low cal mayonnaise for regular mayonnaise!  Maybe in some recipes it works fine, but for my mom's potato salad recipe - nothing but real mayo would work.  I say, if you have to substitute for low cal mayo, maybe you should take only half, then put your fork down!  I say, have fun!

Looking at the ingredients youd never guess this makes good chili. The only reason I didnt give it 5 stars is that it is a bit soupy. I found it got thicker with each reheat. I made this for guests so instead of the ground beef I used two pounds of sirloin which I cubed and braised. If you like super chunky chili, I think you could easily double the non-liquid ingredients. But, I would make it just as is the first time.

text:
Fantastic! I made this for 20 servings. It called for 2 cans of tomato sauce, the only change I made was to use 1 can tomato sauce and 2 cans of rotel tomatoes. I brought it to a boil, turned down heat to a med boil for about 45 min., put it in a crock pot and simmered on low for about 6 hours. I made this 3 times over Thanksgiving week for 3 different groups of people. My husband can not stand chili and he even enjoyed it. I think it is even better the next day.

Display Name:
Christine Notis
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/29264.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe gets 5 stars not only for its taste, but for its ease of preparation.  This was the first time I had ever made chili and I know now that I will be making it often.  The spices were great.  I made only a few changes.  Instead of garlic powder, I used about 8-10 gloves of fresh garlic (I follow the philosophy that one can never have too much garlic).  After I browned the meat (I used 96% lean), I removed it and then sauted the onions, celery, green pepper, and lastly the garlic with a little bit of olive oil in the same pot.  I simmer the meat for about 30 minutes before adding the beans because I didn't want the beans to fall apart.  I used two cans of dark red kidney beans and one can of black beans and for me the ratio of beans to meat was perfect.  I served the chili with fresh baked corn bread.  I can't wait to eat the leftoevers tomorrow!

text:
Well rounded easy chili recipe. We were out of town recently and I needed to make a chili for a chili party. I had most of the ingredients on hand at our vacation home, so I decided to go with this recipe. I followed the recipe with only 2 changes. I used low sodium V8 in place of the regular tomato juice and accidentally forgot to purchase celery, which I will add next time b/c I like the flavor cooked celery brings to other dishes I make. I sauted the onion and bell pepper before adding all ingredients together. I was fortunate I had the time to make a day ahead and agree that it is better the second day, as most dishes of this type tend to be as the flavors have more time to meld together.  Good solid recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4399500.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If I hadn't listened to the comments it definitely would've been soupy, so 4 stars for the recipe as written but  BEST CHILI EVER with the simple changes. If you like soupy and don't like tomato bits, follow as written! If you like it hearty, try this: I subbed the tomato juice for tomato sauce and tomato sauce/bell pepper for 3 10oz cans of Rotel (diced tomatoes w/ green chilis). I also drained Everything and rinsed the beans, and the chili came out perfectly thick and hearty with no need to add corn meal. This is my first time making chili and I nailed it, so it has to be easy- I'm so glad I didn't go with the more complicated recipe on this site.  And last tidbit, I precisely halved this recipe and it was the perfect amount (about 4 big bowls) for a couple with leftovers or small family with none. Hope this helps!

text:
As others recommended, I substituted tomato sauce for the tomato juice (46 oz) and diced tomatoes for the 29 oz of tomato sauce.  The beans I used were one can each kidney and pinto.  After browning the meat, I put it along with all remaining ingredients in a crock pot and cooked on low for about 7 hours.  That was for my convenience, as I was going to be gone for that length of time.  My husband and I ate it twice, topped with sour cream, grated cheddar and sliced green onions.  I froze the remainder which will easily provide another 2+ meals for us.   We both liked this a lot!

text:
Really like this recipe.  I've grown up making chili and I always cooked the onions, celery and bell pepper until it was tender before adding the rest.  In the fall it's fun to roast a hatch pepper and peel it and dump it into the chili.  It doesn't increase the heat that much.  I also experiment with different chili powders.  We really like chipotle chile flavor.  I love club crackers in my chili and my husband says no way.  Well we both can eat chili for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  Great recipe.  We always have cornbread with lots of honey with our chili.  Thanks.

text:
*cut the recipe down for a smaller family and changed the servings to 5*

the spices make this chili taste the way it does and I followed them exactly. DELICIOUS. perfect straight forward chili recipe.

What I love most is that you just throw it all in the pot, stir and cook. Only need to brown the meat separately and you can do that while you're prepping everything else.

I added some frozen corn to mine, omitted the bell pepper b/c I didn't have any on hand, added a full  medium sized onion, used 2 14-oz cans tomato sauce & 1 lg can crushed tomatoes instead of the tomato juice. Threw maybe a cup of water to add some liquid. Used a large can of red kidney beans. 

I changed things but nothing about the spices and that's what I think makes it what it is.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Reliable recipe and worthy of being in your repertoire. Knowing ahead of time that I don't like Kidney beans, I substitute Pintos. Chili without beans is often called "Texas" chili... a misnomer because Texans like beans the way Mungo likes beans. Don't skimp on the chili powder. No, no! But do use a premium chili powder. Your chili dish will never be any better than the chili spices used in it. Morton's Chili Blend, if you can find it, or Schilling. Gephardt's if that's all you can find. And taste it before you decide on the cumin... some chili blends already have cumin in them. Good chili isn't necessarily hot; it is, however, well spiced and flavorful. I'm more inclined toward crushed tomatoes or tomato puree, but out on the cattle drives where chili was invented (to use up less than prime beef scraps) they probably didn't tomatoes at all. It's a very personal dish, but some chuck-wagon cooks were buried beside the trail just because of their chili.
Review:
Rating:
5

I also, instead of tomato sauce and tomato juice, I just used kroger brand diced tomatoes chili ready, and they added beautiful texture to the chili as well as made it meatier. Everyone loved the recipe, including a couple people who really dislike chili. Definitely making this recipe again!

text:
I loved this chili recipe! I followed it almost entirely except I omitted the celery (not a fan) and I slow cooked it on low for a few hours in my dutch oven so the flavors would have time to marry. I also did what other reviewers suggested and added cornmeal. It took the chili from wonderful to amazing! I like spicy so I also added more cayenne pepper until it was spicy enough for me.  I served it with Grandma's Buttermilk Cornbread (also on this site). Thanks for posting!

text:
This chili rocks! okay...like many others, I use this recipe as a base. I substitute ground turkey for beef, tomato sauce for juice, diced tomatoes for sauce, anaheim chiles for bell peppers (for a bit more spice). I also use 3 cans of three beans instead of 2 cans red beans. I put it all together in a large frying pan then throw it in a crock pot on low for at least 6 hours. It is so delicious. We made it for a party last night and people were raving about it I just finished the last bowl for lunch and looking forward to when we'll have it again. Make it along with a pan of cornbread and you've hit a home run!!! Thank you George Couch. LOVE LOVE LOVE it!!!

Even though Ive been making my mother-in-laws chili recipe for years, I tried this recipe because it was recommended by another cook on the buzz.  I slightly tweaked this recipe such as adjusting the seasoning, and adding molasses instead of the sugar which I feel rounds out the flavor.   I prefer chili to have more red kidney beans and would add more the next time.  However, having said that, this recipe is delicious Im sure without any changes and is easy to adjust to suit your taste.  I'll be making this again.

text:
This was very good chili.  I am not usually a fan of chili, so I only served myself a small bowl and I ended up going back for seconds.  My husband is a huge fan of chili and he had thirds.  After reading the reviews, I subbed 1 qt tomato sauce, 1 pt juice + @2Tbsp tomato paste, and 1 pt diced tomatoes for the juice and sauce called for in the recipe.  That worked out really well for us, but next time I will probably just do 1 qt sauce and 1 qt diced tomatoes.  I also omitted the black pepper since my son is allergic and I bumped up the cayenne pepper to 1/2 tsp to account for the missing black pepper.  And I did use 2 full cans of drained and rinsed red beans, rather than just 2 cups.  We served this over noodles like in the picture.  Very tasty, thanks!

This was really good. The flavor reminded me of the chili you buy at Wendy's--but better.  I followed the recipe for the most part, keeping the spices the same with the exception of adding 1 TB worchestire.  I used one 15 oz can of diced tomatoes and then filled that same can twice with tomatoe juice. It just seemed strange not to have some diced tomatoes in chili! I also added two drained cans of red beans, instead of 2 cups.  Just read the recipe wrong, but I'm glad I did.  I probably had an extra 1/2 pound of hamburger. One more comment:  I made one batch the night before and the next one the next morning.  The one that had cooked longer was less sweet... go figure!

text:
Only changes I made were adding 1/2 can of drained whole kernel and a 1/4 tsp of red pepper flakes. I did use 1 can of diced tomatoes and 1 can of diced tomatoes with green chillies in place of the tomato juice, simply because that is what I had on hand. Had several chili recipes in my box until I tried this one, now i only have one.

None
text:
fantastic! i used 1 can chili beans, 1 can red beans, 1 can great northern beans, and 2 cans of black beans and then followed others suggestions to use tomato sauce (instead of juice) and petite diced tomatoes (instead of sauce). Towards the end, I realized that it did need more liquid so I added about 30 oz. of V8 juice for health reasons and flavor. I omitted the green pepper because I didn't have any but added some sauteed shredded carrots. Delicious!

text:
I made the recipe mostly as is, minus the green pepper and added 1 can kidney and 1 can red beans for interest, oh and only 1 lb beef--perfect porportion to the other ingredients. The flavor was great, not too tomato-ey/glorified tomato soup as other reviewers said. The consistency was perfect.  Also, a great balance of sweet and spicy.  However, it could stand to be a bit hotter to me and I'm not a lover of super spicey foods.  I made it for guests and got nothing but compliments.  They were curious what was in it to give it such a unique flavor. Served with sliced green onions, sour cream and cornbread.

text:
Even great using shredded chicken. I make the base of the chili (without the meat) in a crockpot and then use some of the liquid from it to cook the chicken (cut into cubes or strips) in a separate pan. Once fully cooked I toss it in with the rest of the ingredients in the crockpot and let cook for 8 hours.

text:
I make this fairly often, but I have trimmed the meat to one pound of 93% lean ground turkey, and I am using three cans of diced tomatoes instead of the tomato juice / sauce.  I cut the chili powder down to 2 tbsp to reduce the sodium, and I don't include any salt.  I throw in as many veggies as the crock pot will allow, and it still tastes great!

text:
This is a great base recipe as others mentioned. I substituted the tomato juice for sauce and sauce for diced tomatoes and for some reason, my chili came out with a strong tomato flavor. Too strong for my liking so I added some more spices, sauteed jalapenos in butter-poured it in, and added a tablet of Abuelita-Mexican style chocolate, and added cornstarch. The chocolate gave it a suddle mole flavor. I will try this recipe again but maybe follow the rules next time to see how it is originally =)

I did a lot of chili recipe testing a few years ago using recipes from the Food Network site. My favorite was Emeril's Chuck Wagon Chili w/ some of the veggies from his Vegetarian chili. The flavors are amazing. But I wanted to try something new + start checking out AllRecipes, and so I made this chili (despite it's regular everyday chili ingredients) thinking there must be something fantastic about it because of the reviews. I'm eating it right now. It's ok. I added cheese to flavor it up some. It's good - I'm enjoying it - but I dont see why it's getting so many awesome reviews. I dont think it's terrible but I dont think it steps outside the bounds of just an average chili.

My girlfriend made some chili which was the best I had ever had. I forgot to get her recipe so searched for one. This is it. I now make this chili recipe about every 2 weeks. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i have made this recipe for a few months now it has been a huge success. i did make a couple changes just due to personal preference. i add 2 cans of dark red kidney beans as well as 2 cans of diced tomatoes. i also add a jalapeno and half the seeds for more spice. i do not add the entire bottle of tomato juice in on most occasions - i found with the extra tomatoes it can make it too soupy - i let it cook for a while and then add only as needed. the last two times i have made this i used ground turkey and found that both my husband and i liked it better. this really is an easy recipe and it makes great leftovers and freezes well too.

text:
Wow was this an awesome chili!  I was a bit skeptical looking at the ingredients... but made it near-exactly as stated.  (I used one can of chili beans and one can of red beans, rather than two cans of red beans.)  The flavors are subtle and complex at the same time.  The ratio of everything is perfect -- a little crunchy, a little spicy, a little meaty.  This makes a gigantic portion.  I served it the next day to a family that snubs their noses at leftovers -- but added in macaroni.  We had chilimac and it was still tasted great.  Again everyone enjoyed it.  This is my new recipe!  Thank you for sharing it.

text:
This is THE chili recipe! It would be great as is, but I recommend a few modifications. Instead of the tomato juice I use tomato sauce and instead of the tomato sauce I use petite diced tomatoes as others have suggested. I also use a whole green pepper and add mined garlic (fresh or jarred). For a little spice, I add chopped smoked roasted green chilies and add more cayenne pepper then in the recipe. For the beans, I enjoy 1 can of dark kidney and 1 can of black.

text:
Good as written, better if you substitute the sauce for paste or diced tomatoes. I've made this numerous times and I just add the seasonings at random, I don't measure them out (but I did the first time I made this). It's a good recipe to use if you don't want to experiment, but it's also good as a base if you want to add additional ingredients or different amounts of spices.

text:
I have to start by saying that I do not like to change a recipe and then rate it. I like to make the recipe as written, I will read the reviews and take the most popular suggestions and follow them. However, with this recipe I started to make this thinking that I had all of the ingredients but I quickly found out that I did not! I browned the ground beef, added the chopped onion and celery. Then I added 1 28oz. can of crushed tomatoes because I did not have a large can of tomato sauce. I had 1 16 oz can of tomato sauce. Then I added 1 small can of tomato paste, brown sugar and water. I hated that I changed it so much but this is what I had to work with. Other than the changes I had to make, everything else was as written and I have to say everyone here loved it! It is a really fantastic chili. I will make this over and over!

text:
My family - 3 kids included really enjoys this recipe. We leave out the celery and bell pepper. I use one 15 oz can tomato sauce, one can of petite diced tomatoes with green chiles and the I add the tomato juice until it's the consistency we like - usually about 2/3 of the total recommended amount of juice. Then I just adjust the spices to our tastes - I add a smidge more cayenne and salt. Other than that, I follow the listed amounts. We love it!

city:

country:

text:
Excellent recipe, a keeper & I will definitely make again (and again).  I am a "first time exact recipe follower" but I did change things, only because I got about 1/2 way through it and realized I didn't have all the ingredients.  I subbed refrigerated minced garlic for the garlic powder (1/2 tsp in the browning meat, 3/4 tsp in the liquid mixture) and subbed 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes for the cayenne.  Next time I will make it exactly as written.  I would say, though, that it is a forgiving recipe if you want to change it up.  I also sauteed the onions & celery prior to putting it liquid mix as hubby likes the veggies very tender in chili.  We like it spicy, so we topped it with jalepenos, cheese and a dash of tabasco :)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-09-13T13:16:39.897

It was an absolute hit. Thank you for sharing!

text:
I have searched for years for a great chili recipe - and I've finally found one!!  After reading all the reviews - I tried to follow the recipe as closely as possible - but with what I had on hand.  I didn't have tomato juice - so I mixed a can of tomato paste with beer to make the 46oz.  No tomato sauce - so I used canned diced tomatoes (with juice) instead.  Lastly - I didn't have ground beef - but I did have ground venison - so I used it.  Next time I'll actually make a trip to the store and get everything I need.  Because - if it is this good with the few changes I had to make to accommdate my pantry - I can't imagine how good it would be following the recipe exactly.  This is a winner!!!!!!

text:
This was really fantastic chili, George! Just the right amount of spice and heat. I like that, then others are able to increase the heat at the table to their liking. This was really soupy and my husband loved that aspect. I chopped up 1 onion, 3 stalks of celery split lengthwise then chopped, and a half a green pepper. I couldn't find the garlic powder lost in my myriad of unorganized spices, so I tossed in a couple of tsps. of minced garlic. My only addition was an extra can of beans, 1/2 tsp of chipotle chile pepper and 1/2 tsp ancho chile pepper powder. I simmered this for 3 hours with the lid on. This was awesome chili and definitely highly recommended, but our personal favorite is still chili I.

Display Name:
VIOLETTBLUE
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a GREAT base recipe to build my idea of the 'ultimate' chili recipe upon.  

Much like the other reviewers, I tweaked this recipe to my own tastes.  Here is what I did:

I browned my ground beef, then added it to a large pot with 4-15oz cans plain tomato sauce and 2-12oz can V8 low-sodium veggie juice.  In the pan I browned the beef in, I then browned 2Tbsp minced garlic, 2Tbsp chopped green chilis (canned), and a chopped sweet vidalia onion, omitting the bell pepper (not one of my favorites).  To the tomato mixture, I omitted the garlic powder (since I already added minced garlic at the beginning), added 1/2 tsp ground coriander, 1 Tbsp paprika, and instead of the 1/4 cup (4 tablespoons) of regular chili powder, I doubled the amount (we like a very stron chili!) and changed the proportions to 6 Tbsp regular chili powder, 1 Tbsp Ancho chili powder, and 1 Tbsp Chipotle chili powder, which gave the chili a wonderfully slightly sweet, smoky undercurrent.  Oh, and I also added 1/2 cup red wine and a full bottle of lager beer to the tomato sauce.  Finally, I added about 2 Tbsp fresh lemon juice and a nice big pinch of dill to the mix.  Then I brought the chili to a boil and let it simmer about a half hour.

So, like I said, I tweaked everything to our tastes and preferences, but ultimately, this was a wonderful base recipe to build upon.  Great mix of flavors, great amount of heat, and definitely a crowd-pleaser!
Review:

text:
This was the first time I've made chili. It was pretty tasty, but it was on  the meaty side for my family, which is just because my family isn't a big meat-eater. I was afraid that it would come out too salty, so I used low-sodium V-8 vegetable cocktail and added more salt to my liking later. I also used fresh garlic instead of powdered (I never use garlic powder), substituted 1 can of red beans with pinto beans, and substituted 1 can of diced tomato with juice instead of tomato sauce. I served this with homemade cornbread, and the meal was hearty. Next time, though, I will cut down on meat and add other vegetables, like more bell peppers, tomatoes and add zucchini, green beans etc.

Good, but watch the spices. I took the suggestions to use turkey and V-8. The turkey does change the texture. This started getting hot when I added the cumin. Cut the chili powder to 1 tbsp. Next time I try it I will cut the cumin and boost the chili powder in hope of getting a better blend.

text:
I am trying to incorporate more beans into my diet so tried this chili recipe.  I made a few changes based on what I had in my pantry.  I used all tomato sauce, no juice, no celery,  red pepper rather than green,  half a jalapeno rather than cayenne and no sugar.   I also grated in a small zuchini at the very end to get a little more veg in.  It was a huge hit and even better the second night.

This was my first chili in over a decade since Im surrounded by people who make better chili than me and never needed to try. Its a perfect starter recipe, especially with picky kids. The texture was really good and even though I forgot to buy green peppers it was very tasty. Us grownups just threw some chalula in ours and that kicked up enough for me. The leftovers made great chili dogs and overstuffed chili cheese omelets. Its going on the regular dinner rotation!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe more times than I can count - I know it by heart now.  It is ALWAYS my go to recipe; I don't make any other type of chili.  Just wanted to add that this also cooks up great in the instant pot for a super fast meal.  Just brown the meat and throw everything in.  I cook it at high pressure for 10 minutes tops and natural release, or just manually release if I'm in a hurry.  Depending on the size of your instant pot though you may need to make half a batch.  Also, word to the wise - a full batch is a huge amount of chili. That's never an issue for us because it reheats and freezes great, but just be aware if fridge or freezer space is an issue!

My family loves this chili--great flavor and freezes well. For those that don't like anything "spicy" they may not like the amount of chili put in this one or the cayenne.

It's delicious!

I have made this for years.  I've had rave reviews and even won a chili cook-off with it.  The only things I change up is that I use V-8 instead of tomato juice, I usually use 1 lb ground beef, 1 lb spicy sausage and I add a small can of rotel to add a little more spice.  I like my chili more soupy so it's perfect for me, and anyone who has tasted it wants the recipe.

I followed the recipe except I cooked the onions with the hamburger, then threw it all in the crockpot.  Since I was making this for  additional family members I wanted to add more stuff!   I added 3 cans of beans (1 black, 1 chili bean and 1 kidney).  I also swapped out the tomato juice for Rotelo diced tomatoes with green chilies.  Oh I added a diced jalapeno.  Everyone loved it.  Even my daughter who doesn't care about chili.  This will be my go to.

text:
I made this with lean ground turkey, and I used 2 red bell peppers, in addition to 1 green bell pepper.  I also added an extra can of kidney beans (about 4 cups total).  I used a full bottle of tomato juice (extra 12 oz or so), added some chopped garlic in addition to the garlic powder. I like spicy chili, so I also added one large jalapeno (finely diced).  Wow, so delicious.  I will be making this again.

text:
It's a great, simple chili recipe that I made the first time by the recipe and we liked it a lot, but this time, I did not have tomato juice or sauce on hand so I substituted four  14.5 oz cans of diced tomatoes that I blended into juice. I also added a half a can of water to the pot along with the "tomato juice". I also increased the veggies to I cup each of pepper, celery and onion and added five cloves of garlic instead of garlic powder.  Fantastic!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is really good as is! Flavorful and rich. I thought it a bit odd that everything was just thrown in a pot and boiled. So I cut up 4-6 slices of bacon and fried it in the pot until it was crispy. I removed it with a slotted soon to a paper towel lined plate to drain so I could use it for garnish later.  In the bacon grease I sauted the onions, celery and peppers for about 10-15 to develop some extra flavor then proceeded with the recipe as instructed (all ingredients in the pot...). I think this additional step provided some extra depth of flavor to the vegetables. Turned out amazing!

text:
Fantastic chili!  My only changes were using two 28oz cans of diced tomatoes, 1 can tomato paste (adding about 5 or 6 cans of water) and doubling up on the cayenne pepper, as we like it spicy.   I put it in the crockpot on high for about 3 hours, then added 1 can kidney, 1 can mixed beans  (drained and rinsed). Cooked for another 1.5 to 2 hours.

Thank you, no need to look for another chili recipe ever again :)

text:
This is a recipe, as is, my entire family loves, and this doesnt take me 2 hours to make! Seasonings are perfect! It is a thin chili as made. The 2nd time I made it, I used 1 lb ground turkey & 1lb hot ground sausage as its all I had on hand. Cooked it in a skillet then drained the fat. I added 1-2 Tbsp of Worcester  sauce,  the onions, celery, spices to saut. Put it all in a crockpot& substituted 2 -14oz cans chopped fire roasted tomatoes for the sauce. Added 1 can beans only & 1-4oz can diced green Chiles. I added tomato sauce and tomato juice until I liked the consistency. I was not sold this was going to work, but after 6 hours in the crock pot on low-it turned out great.

userID:
9140712
Display Name:
Josh & Brandy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
16
favoritesCount:
158
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4499613.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making another chili recipe on here for a while, which is great, but decided to give this a try. The ingredients were somewhat similar in that recipe. The only changes I made with this were the addition of two 15oz cans of stewed tomatoes and I cut back on the tomato juice just a little bit. I also put my seasonings in after the meat browned and gave them some time to cook/toast up. I then deglazed with a little bit of beer and added the tomato sauce, juice, and stewed tomatoes. Simmered for an hour and a half and this was great! Also, I didn't measure the beans. I used one 15oz can of small red kidney beans at the beginning. I then added a 15oz can of Brooks Hot Chili Beans during the last 20min or so. The addition of extra beans, as well as the stewed tomatoes, made this the perfect consistency for me.

I am a VERY picky person about chili. I generally dont like it unless on a hot dog with out the beans. Curtain ones I dont like (especially kidney beans). But this...this was GREAT! I followed the instructions. But instead of cooking on the stove. I cooked and drained the meat and put it all together in the slow cooker. Had it set on high for 4 to 5 hours. My boyfriend and his son who is 7 and can be picky at times also likes it. Im sure Ill be making this again.

text:
This is a great chili that can be altered easily to suit your needs.  The first time I made it, I made it ahead of time and put it in the freezer to take camping.  It froze nicely and tasted great with cheese and cornbread.  The second time I made it I added 2 cocoa squares and cinnamon and less tomato juice to create a Cincinnati chili to serve over pasta.  I also made a vegetarian version using vegetarian 'meat' bits instead of the ground beef and it was a hit as well.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't do many reviews online, but this one had to be written! I have been searching for a good chili recipe and when I read the spices in this one, I knew it was going to be special. I made it last night for our family which usually has 2 teenage boys, my husband and I, but last night we had an extra 2 teenagers. This recipe made a huge pot of chili and was without a doubt the best chili I have ever tasted. My family raved about it. Kudos to the chef because the spices are perfection. The only things I did was add a third pound of meat to give it a little more body and then added a little extra sugar to suit our taste. I also used pinto beans and because my boys aren't crazy about beans, I mashed up one can and mixed it in (which thickened the soup) and then only 1 can of beans was visible:-) It's a wonderful recipe and will be my permanent go-to for chili in the future. It's just delicious!

text:
I replaced the 46 ounces of tomatoe juice with (1) 28 oz. can of crushed tomatoes & a 1/2 cup water. I also added (1) can of chili beans with the (2) cans of dark red kidney beans. I simmered the chili  for 1 1/2 hours. Once done the consistency was perfect. Not to thick & not to liquidy. Melted some taco cheese on top, added some sour cream & corn bread. Walla my husband actually commented how great it was!! That's how I know is was good. This is my go to chili recipe from now on.

text:
Loved this and let me start by saying as a new cook and a skittish cook when it comes to modifying, I DID change a few tiny things based on lots of the reviews. Simple stuff -- instead of 46 ounces of tomato juice, I did 32 ounces (4 cups) and one 14 ounce can of chopped tomatoes with mild green chilis. I did a whole brown onion, a whole green pepper and prob double the celery. One last thing -- instead of 1/2 cup of chili powder I did 3/4 cup (I know, so wild of me lol). That's it! Super low flame, stirred occasionally, turned off the heat after about 1 hr 10 mins (hungry!). Perfection!!! And a nice kick :)

text:
I made this for a chili contest at work and it won! What I liked about this recipe is there are no chunks of tomato (I do not like tomato chunks or crushed tomato).  I followed the recipe but added smoked paprika, two diced habanero peppers, and a bottle of pale ale.  I don't like spicy food but I knew that most of my co-workers do, so this is the recipe I went with.  When I make this for myself I will not add the peppers and may add some spaghetti noodles.

text:
I have made this chili recipe several times and it has turned out amazing every time. I did make a few modifications after making it as it the first time though. My family is not of fan of green peppers in chili so I left those out and I also omitted the celery. I did add a bottle of beer and this really made the sauce taste outstanding. I also added more chili powder and cayenne pepper than the recipe called for as we like it a little more spicy. Happy cooking as this recipe is a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I've never made chili that didn't have a can of diced tomatoes in it.  So I added a 28oz can and used only a 14oz can of tomato sauce.  I also had some jalapeno peppers that needed to be used up so I chopped up two of them and added them.  I also added a bit more celery than was called for and just a pinch of cinnamon.  Otherwise everything else was the same.  Simmered it for more than 2 1/2 hours so it thickened up to chili-like consistency.  Maybe it's the chili powder we bought from the ethnic aisle at the grocery store but this chili was very HOT! Hubby liked it that way but if not for the sour cream and nacho chips to eat it with, I would not have been able to eat it.  However it was very tasty and this is probably the only way I'll make chili again.  I might have to cut back on the chili powder just a wee bit though.

text:
After reading many positive reviews of this recipe I was excited to make this. I did exactly as the recipe  said but it was really really spicy. I could have known by adding a pretty  big amount of chili powder that it would be a bit spicy but this was way to spicy for us. Maybe we're not used to eating this spicy. I tried to tone it down by adding honey and lemon juice and some sour creme while serving but I didn't finish my plate. I'm going to add some more tomato sauce, beans, onions and groundbeef and the others spices except for the chili and cayenne to the left overs (which are a lot). Hopefully this will tone down the spiciness of the recipe. It smelled delicious though.
I reread the recipe to see if I did something wrong because I started doubting myself, but can't discover anything I did wrong.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
You'll get great chili from this recipe, and it's five stars exactly as written. I've made it as written many times because it's a guaranteed hit. With that said, I sometimes enhance the recipe. I'll add a can or two of V8 and cook it longer (2-3 hours) to burn off that extra liquid. I'll also omit the added salt and add one beef bouillon cube, one can of diced tomotoes with green chilies, and two dashes of Tapatio hot sauce which will give it a low-medium heat. If time permits, make it the day before and reheat when ready to serve. Tastes even better next day.

text:
I adapted this for my pressure cooker (instant pot) I threw everything into my pressure cooker and set in on manual for 30 minutes. I did use pre soaked dry beans and diced tomatoes and tomatoe sauce as substitutes. I also threw in a can of diced green chilies. When it was done I slow released 15 minutes and then added some frozen corn and let it bubble for about 5 minutes. I served it with shredded Mexican cheese, sour cream, and tortilla chips and it was AMAZING. A one pot meal that was super fast.

text:
I followed the recipe with the following exceptions: 1) Substituted V8 vegetable juice in place of tomato juice, 2) Used Italian seasoning in place of oregano, 3) Added several squirts of Frank's Hot Sauce, 4) I did not add any salt.
 I thought the chili was thin when I started to simmer it on the stove so I browned an extra pound of ground meat and added it in. That seemed to help the consistency. I would reconsider the amount of tomato juice otherwise.  Everyone liked it, you could definitely taste the flavor of the spices. I would make it again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this recipe for the first time two weeks ago and it was a huge success. I was mindful of the reviews that said it was too soupy by adding only about 2/3 of the tomato juice initially then gradually added more during the cooking until the consistency was right. For personal preference I used half as many beans and added one diced jalapeno for a little more heat. Definitely follows the chili principle where the longer you simmer the better! I froze the leftovers in ziploc bags and they reheat very well, maybe even better than the first time. I plan on making it again this weekend for the superbowl and I'm excited to have a bunch of easy leftovers again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The taste is fantastic but the  recipe could be rated differently depending on your tastes.  My husband and son rated this a 5 plus since they love a chili with chunky, somewhat crispy vegetables with a more "brothy" base.  My daughter's and I like a thicker richer base with the veggies completely cooked down so rated this a 3.  That being said, I'm sure the recipe can be tweaked to personal preferences by sauting the vegetables for awhile before and adding a roux to thicken the sauce.  Overall, quick, easy and very good

This is my staple chili recipe! Like many others, I have made this recipe EXACTLY as listed, but personal preference is the essence of cooking. That being said, the only subtle changes are: substitute a can of black beans for a can of red beans and add 1/4 cup of corn starch for thickness. Soooooo good! Thank you for contributing this recipe! When the cool North wind blows, and the air is damp with the smell of Autumn, my mind transverses to the place of good homecooked meals like this!

Display Name:
MRS.STORY
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Husband really liked this chili.  I would have liked it a little spicier, but I went easy because he and the kid don't like spicy.  I always choose the lower sodium option when getting ingredients.  I screwed up and didn't have the tomato juice.  Thought about putting in lower sodium V8, but decided to put in a small can of tomato paste and a carton of lower sodium beef broth instead.  Put in a little less than 1/4 cup chili powder, knowing I could add more later.  Used 3 cans lower sodium kidney beans, rinsed well.  I didn't add any salt.  Let it cook, and toward the end I tasted & made some adjustments.  Put in a bit of ancho chili powder (for a little smokiness), paprika, some more garlic powder, and some beef Better Than Bouillon.  Husband had three bowls, and had some for lunch today. ~~~ Thanks for sharing the recipe -- I'll probably make this one again!

text:
Best chili recipe (and I've tried quite a few).  I had to improvise with ingredients on hand:  16 oz tomato sauce, 8 oz can of seasoned diced tomatoes, and 1 can of Dr. Pepper (my husband drinks the stuff by the case). Everything else as listed.  I also premix all the dry herbs in a small bowl before adding to the main mixture.  I prepared it in my slow cooker and let's just say the batch  didn't make it till dinnertime.  After my boys caught a whiff aout 3 hours in, they were dishing themselves out bowls, and it was all gone before dinnertime.  Next time I'll double the batch. :)

text:
For a spur of the moment decision this came out great!  I tweaked it a little based on what I had handy, halving the recipe (I'm one person...I can't eat chili for 10 days..) and adding diced tomatoes with jalapanos in place of the tomato juice. I like my chili more solid than soupy :)  Used leftover frozen onions (didn't measure) and green peppers (didn't measure those either) and left out the celery because I didn't have any.  Came out great though--easy recipe to remember the next time I'm in the store and an older gentleman says "Today is football day!!" and I think to myself..hey...chili sounds good! :)

userID:
8240739
Display Name:
LadyMierKat
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
41
favoritesCount:
103
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This very easy to make and it tasted great!  I cooked this in my crockpot - 2 hours on high and 2 hours on low.  The flavors merged beautifully.  I realized too late that I didn't have any cumin so I substituted 1 tsp paprika and 1 tsp ground thyme - weird, I know, but it actually worked well.  My husband likes a very meaty chili, so I used almost 3 lbs meat, 2-48 oz cans crushed tomatoes and 1 can tomato paste.  For the beans, I followed another user's suggestion and did 1 can chili beans and 1 can kidney beans.  I have very happy with how it turned out - especially without cumin.  My husband was happy and ended up having 3 servings for dinner!  Oh, I did not think it was spicy at all.  A little warmth on the backend, so there is a lot of wiggle room for more heat options.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This was my first time making chilli and it was a success. Both my boyfriend and his roommate kept commenting on how good it was. We poured it over Fritos and added some cheese and it was delicious! At first I thought it would be too liquidy but it thickened up once we put it in out bowls. I did do things a little differently- I almost doubled the beans by adding two 15oz cans of red beans due to my fear of it being too watery and it  worked out great. My boyfriend normally hates beans but he still loved it. I also cooked everything on the stove for the first 15-20 minutes and then transferred it to a crockpot on high for the next 2 hours. Worked out so I am happy! When everyone is in a food coma after eating your meal, you know you did something right ??

We used this recipe as the base for a veggie chili by using tvp instead of the beef and it turned out great. text:
This recipe is so easy and so delicious! Don't worry about measuring the veggies exactly, I always put in whatever I have left over in the fridge and it's perfect every time.  The only substitution I make is instead of the cayenne pepper, I put in 1-2 jalapeo, deseeded and deveined.  I add back seeds depending on my audience.  I've made this different ways...as written and also browning and draining the meat then mixing all ingredients in the crockpot and leaving it on Low all day (6 hours).  Both were perfect and guests always asked for the recipe.

text:
I make one simular to this...I'd like for folks to try.Cook 1-2 lbs. ground beef,season it with onion powder & seasoning salt.Drain.Put in large pot,with tomato sauce(you choose how much)and 2 cans of pinto beans not drained.Add 1 lg. can of diced green chilli's,cumin and chilli powder.To make it spicier,I add a few good squirts of Franks Redhot sauce.We either eat in a bowl topped with shredded cheese,and crackers,or over cooked elbow noodles.Fast & easy,taste real good.(sometimes we use onions on top)

text:
This is a great chili recipe, but really lends itself to modifying it to your own preferences!!  I've made the recipe as it is...but have started to "play" with it a bit and now I like it even more.  I decrease tomato sauce to 8 oz and add 28 oz crushed tomato, 1 can tomato paste and 2 cups of beef broth. Add 28 oz drained diced tomatoes and use 1 can black beans and 1 can of kidney beans (both drained and rinsed).  To the seasonings I add 2 T more chili powder, 1 teaspoon of chipotle pepper and 1 extra teaspon of cumin.  So good...my hubby's favorite chili!!!!

UPDATE: THIS WAS SOMEWHAT BETTER ON DAY 2. THE CHILI MELLOWED A BIT AND WASN'T NEARLY AS TOMATOEY (WHICH I DIDN'T CARE FOR). I TOPPED A LEFTOVER BAKED POTATO (HALF) WITH SOME CHILI, CHEESE, SOUR CREAM AND CHOPPED ONION. REMINDED ME OF WENDY'S FAMOUS BAKED POTATO! MMMMMM.... Neither my hubs or I cared for this at all (sorry!). We both felt this was way too tomatoe-y. Having said this, I'm not sure why we had such an aversion to this while we liked George's "It's Chili by George!!". While we didn't fall in love with that one (it would not be the first recipe I turn to when the chili mood strikes), we certainly didn't dislike it as much as we did this. Other than a few minor differences, the two really are pretty much the same recipe, so I'm stumped. :) Contrary to the norm, I followed George's directions to the letter for the most part. My only change was with the cooking method. I decided to slow cook my chili (9 hours on low setting) rather than cook it on the stovetop as directed. If you're looking for a highly-rated and EASY chili recipe, try Deb's blue ribbon chili or Danielle's slow cooker chili. Both are FANTASTIC and the stellar reviews are proof of that. Serving this "chili mac" style with all the fixins' MADE our meal (the chili certainly didn't...). Maybe this will float your boat, but it did nothing for us. Thanks anyways, George. :)
