A fantastic recipe!! I took many other's advice and changed the tomato juice to tomato sauce and the tomato sauce to diced tomatoes. I also increased the chopped green pepper to 1/2 cup and changed the beans to 2 cups each of dark kidney beans and pinto beans (both drained and washed). I let this big delicious pot of chili simmer on the stove for 2 1/2 hours and it was one of the best foods I've ever had. Definitely going to make this again!

city:

country:
None
text:
Delicious!! I have been making this recipe for a few years now. Over that course of time, I have tweaked it just a bit until I found the thickness that I was looking for. With the help of some reviewers, I too changed the tomato juice to tomato sauce and the sauce to diced tomato (I use diced tomato with green chile for a little heat.) I then use 3!! Yes, you read right, 3 cans of beans. I use one of pinto, one of kidney, and the last can is black beans. I take half of each can (with a little of the bean liquid) and blend it in a blender to make a thickening agent for the chili. Then I just add more veggies than what the recipe calls for because WHY NOT!! :-p Very yummy! No complaints from anyone.

text:
I made this today, I think it has a strong base but I found it to be a bit grainy for me, like I could still feel the grit of the spices, so next time I use this I will be sure to cook the spices a few minutes before I add everything else, that way they are melded together and that grit has a chance to cook out. But I will definitely use the base for this again.

The first time I ever made chili and it came out great! It was super simple to prep. I cut the recipe in half and cooked it in a big sauce pan. I also only used 2 tbsp + 1 tsp of chili powder b/c my husband doesn't like it to be too spicy.  I sauteed the veggies in EVOO before I added the rest of the ingredients. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cooked this last week and it was a huge hit. I scaled it down and still froze some of it for a later date. However I did make changes. I sauted my onions and garlic in EVOO then threw in crockpot. I then browned my hamburger meat, drained, and put in crockpot. I used a vegetable juice instead of tomato juice and I chopped up about 4 Roma tomatoes and 1/4 of a jalapeno and sauted in EVOO. I cooked up some dried pinto beans to use instead of can beans. I did not make any chages to the seasonings. I put everything in the crockpot and cooked on high for about 3 hrs then turned to low for about 2 hrs. The leftovers were even better!! This is my new chili recipe.

text:
I grew up in Texas and this chili deserves to win a cook-off blue ribbon.  THe flavors are well-balanced and satisfying.  I've made it several times with only one change -- I used crushed tomatoes instead of tomato juice because I never manage to remember to buy tomato juice.  (It makes the sauce thick and savory anyway!)  I've also made it with extra garlic, an added can of diced mild chilis and even a palmful of grated sharp cheddar.  Yum.  This is a great staple chili recipe that doesn't disappoint.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipes was awesome but I did make some modifications because I wanted to make it more healthy and lowfat.  I used the spices as stated except added an additional teaspoon of cumin.  I used only 1 lb. of ground beef.  Instead of tomato sauce I used 2 (15oz) cans of diced tomates, 1 with chili's one without.  Instead of tomato juice I used 1 large (28oz) can of crushed tomatoes. I omitted the celery and onion because of preference but used a total of 2 chopped green peppers.  For the beans I used 1 can of light red kidney, 1 can of dark red kidney, 1 can of pinto and 1 can of black beans. I did purchase 1 can of tomato sauce in cause it needed to be thinner but didn't need it. Awesome flavor with moderate spice.  The family loved it!!!

text:
I don't like chili, however this is really good! It makes a TON of chili, so if you are feeding your family, I would cut it in half. I kept a small container for leftovers, but have 2 LARGE throw-away freezer containers in the freezer. 
I served this with cornbread, cheese, and sour cream. My kids weren't too into it, as they thought it was spicy. I'm a spice wimp, and I thought it was just right. I didn't have cayenne pepper available, so I added a touch more chili pepper to the mix. I also added the 1/4 C of cornmeal suggested by another member to thicken it up, and it was the right consistency.
Thank you for such a great recipe! I'm thinking of adding a little chocolate next time. That's what a lot of my friends here in TX add instead of sugar.

text:
This is a very good, basic chili. I left out the green pepper and celery since i didn't have any on hand and it was still very good. I will probably add a little more chili powder in the future since it was pretty mild. My kids loved it though. Served it w/corn bread, sour cream and cheese on the side. They ate all but 1 bowl (that i had for lunch the next day) and this makes a huge recipe. Everyone went back for 2nds. Simmered the pot for about 1 1/2 hrs and it was perfect. Not runny but nice and thick. I was worried about using tomato juice but it worked well. Thanks for the recipe.

This is really good, and now is my go to chili recipe. I did change one thing on the recipe and I used tomato sauce instead of soup because I didn't have any on hand. BUT it was perfect and I have not used the original in fear of ruining a good thing. I also didnt think I would like celery in chili, so I cut it up really thin and it is really nice!
This is simple, easy, and yummy!

Wonderful!  I made this last night for a football game because my brother in law requested chili.  I did change a few things,  I used a 29oz can of tomato sauce, 2 14 oz cans of stewed tomatos and 1 10oz can of tomato puree and I sauteed the green pepper and onion before adding it to the chili.  I also omitted the celery as a personal preference for my family and it was awesome!!  Even my sister raved about it and had leftovers tonight.  I served it with a Spoon bread which really made this top notch.  Will be adding this to my recipe box for sure

text:
Great chili receipe as is! I made a few adjustments for my own taste preferences. I sauteed 3 teaspoons of minced garlic before adding ground beef to add some flavor in the meat. I omitted the celery and added 1 can of kernel corn for a nice contrast of sweet and spicy flavors.  I also added 2 tablespoons of chopped jalepeno for some extra spice. After 1.5 hours of simmering, I served it with fresh baked corn bread and topped it off with a dallop of sour cream and fresh cilantro.

This is an excellent dish, all the flavors blend perfectly together! Thanks for the great receipe George!

text:
This is, by far, the best chili I've ever had.  Husband and the kids loved it.  We froze some in lunch size portions which husband took to work instead of frozen storebought dinners (much healthier and tastier).  We substituted tomato juice with tomato sauce, and substituted the tomato sauce the recipe called for with stewed tomatoes.  We also added one fresh diced jalepeno, no seeds.  We made Mexican Cornbread from this site, and it was great!  (We froze that too so husband could take a piece with his chili for lunch.)  This recipe is one to keep in your family recipes to pass on to future generations.  WONDERFUL!

text:
Yum Yum Yum. This was the first time I had ever made chili, so I was just looking for a recipe for some guidence, but I ended up following this recipe exactly. I was a little short of 1/4 cup chili power, but I though what I had was great. It wasn't what I would call hot, so I added a few dashes of Louisana hot sauce to each bowel. I am eating the leftovers now at work and they are delish. By boyfriend and my co-workers all complimented it. 
Also, I substituted the juice for sauce (one and a half big cans) and the sauce for diced tomatos as others suggested because I like thick chili. It was very good and tomato-y. Would be great on spagetti!

country:
None
text:
My family thought this chili taste like our favorite chili at Wendy's. I substituted 1 can of red beans to kidney beans, and the other to pinto beans. You do not need to add the sugar. If you want it to taste sweeter, just add basil; which naturally brings out the sweetness in tomatoes. I used stewed tomatoes, chopped up because I like little chunks of tomatoes. Once I added the sugar, it was too sweet, so I ended up using 2 bay leaves to cut the sweetness. I would make this recipe again, with my little tweeking.

text:
Very yummy chili.  I didn't change a thing.  I diced the onions, pepper, and celery very small by using a food processor.  We don't like chunky chili.  I was a little worried because I was impatient and tried it as soon as I got everything in the pot together and it tasted really tomatoey.  However, I let it go for the 1 1/2 hrs and it was so wonderful when done.  Perfect blend of spiciness and tomato flavor.  Perfect consistency - not too runny and not too thick.  I will be using it in a chili cookoff in a couple of weeks - hopefully the judges like it as much as we did.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is wonderful!!  Like many of you, I did make a few changes based on others' suggestions.  I replaced the tomato juice and 29oz can of tomatoes with 1 14.5oz can diced tomatoes with Jalapeno and 1 14.5 oz can diced with mexican spices.  I also added 2-15oz cans tomato sauce. I used 2 cans pinto beans rather than red beans (that is what I had on hand) and I added 1-4oz can fire roasted hot chiles and 1/4 t red pepper (we like our food spicy).  Everything else I did the same except I cooked it all in the crockpot while I was at work!  Leftovers freeze up GREAT!

text:
This recipe was yummy! It definately had a kick to it! Use caution and add the chili powder slowly and see how much spice you can handle. Made a few other changes as well: used diced tomatoes and tomato sauce instead; added half a cup of chopped carrots; used a few cloves of fresh minced garlic instead; added a teaspoon of paprika; used half kidney beans and half pimento beans. Served it with a heaping spoonful of sour cream, some grated cheddar cheese, and fresh cilatro to garnish. Had some fresh dinner rolls to sop up the chili too! Definately a keeper in my recipe box!

text:
This is a staple recipe in my house.  I use the recipe as a base and tweek depending on the ingredients I have in stock. I always half the recipe for me and husband (makes plenty).  Without exception I never have tomatoe juice so I instead puree whatever tomatoe products I have that adds up to the amount of oz the recipe calls for (diced tomatoes, whole, petite cut, whatever) and add the small can tomtoe sauce or paste (again, whatever I have). I use the spice ratio almost to a tee....just add a bit more cayanne.  I love that you brown meat, drain, add everything, and cover.  Easy, great tasting.

text:
Delicious chili and so comforting on a chilly night! Very easy to make too. I have made this chili many times using different canned tomato variations, and bell pepper and bean varieties and it has always turned out wonderful. It's easy to tweak to suit your taste. I like to use 2 bell peppers, 2 cans beans, and celery with the leaves. The longer you let it simmer the better, the flavors really get to meld together. Serve with some sharp cheddar and monterey jack, green onion, olives, and sliced avocado-warm cornbread too!

Display Name:
kelcampbell
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3294500.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My DH and I made this for dinner tonight and it was delicious...although we changed so many things that we probably should just post our own recipe!  Here is what we did:  cut the recipe in half to 5 servings; used 2 cups tomato juice; omitted the tomato sauce; added 1 can "spicy red pepper" diced tomatoes; 4 cloves garlic; omitted the green pepper; added 1 can kidney beans and 1 can brown beans in molasses; we also increased the amount of sugar to about 1 Tbsp and the amount of chili powder by an additional 2 tsp.  We simmered stovetop for about 2 hours and then transferred to a slow cooker for about 3 or 4 hours.  The end result was absolutely delicious served with sour cream, grated cheddar and sliced green onion.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-12-27T12:57:01.497

text:
Easy to make, uses a variety of spices but well-balanced. I substitute ground turkey for the meat and use a couple cans of diced italian tomatoes to give it a chunkier texture (instead of the sauce). I haven't tried another chili recipe since I found this one. I especially like the celery which balances out the spicy flavors. I usually make a pot on Sunday, and it always tastes better the next day.

text:
This was a hit at my football bash tonight! For a party of 6, I ended up using 2 lb of beef (mixture of lean and not-so-lean ground beef), 2 cans of tomato sauce and 1 can of Fire Roasted Diced Tomatoes for extra heat. Not a big fans of beans, so I ended up just using 1 can of red kidney beans. I like the chili a lot hotter so I also added 1 seeded jalapeno pepper plus a few more teaspoons of cayenne and chili powder. Served this with hot dogs and tonnes of cheddar cheese. DELICIOUS!

text:
This is a very good base chili recipe, my husband and I both loved it.  Like other reviewers, I did make changes, they were: adding a bit more garlic because we love it, 1/2-1 cup of chicken broth to give it more liquid, using tomato sauce instead of tomato juice, 2 T. of tomato paste, I used 2lbs. of ground turkey and 2 links of Italian Sausage (no seeds) instead of beef. 

This spiciness of the chili was balanced very nicely by eating Grandmother's Buttermilk Cornbread with it.  The recipe for that can be found here at allrecipes.

text:
This chili was awesome!  I took the advice of others and used a combination of tomato sauce, diced tomatoes, and tomato juice.  I didn't use celery but used a yellow bell pepper along with the green.  I cooked everything but the beans the night before and let it sit in the the fridge overnight.  Then I heated it back up with the beans the next afternoon for lunch.  It was excellent. My father-in-law who doesn't like chili liked it too! I served it with cheddar and sour cream.  Thanks for the great and easy recipe!

this was an EXCELLENT recipe.  tasted fantastic - i made for a friends BDAY dinner along with some slow cooked ribs and i must say the chili was a huge hit.  i made extra hoping for leftovers - but these were gone the next day.  i've since had to give the recipe to most of my guests as they all liked it so much!  

i did make a couple of small changes due to personal preference / dietary concerns.  First, instead of ground beef i used 98% lean turkey and i also added about a pound of mild italian sausage.  instead of using tomato sauce and tomato juice, i used tomato sauce and a can of stewed tomatos.  everything else was per receipe.  Try it - you will NOT be disappointed.

text:
YUM  YUM  YUM!  I wondered about the 1/4 cup of chili powder, but the flavor of this mixture is wonderful!  I did make changes for personal taste & texture, but for me, this was an excellent base to work from.  Like others, I subbed out the tomato juice for 2 of the large cans of tomato sauce (29oz) and then the tomato sauce for 1 large can of diced tomatoes.  I don't care for kidney beans so I used 1 drained can of pinto beans & 1 can of chili beans, partially drained.  Chopped jalepeno pepper was a good addition. I served over macaroni noodles with some cheese & sour cream & it was SO GOOD!!  My husband bragged for days!!

text:
Great recipe for what I needed it for. My 2 teenagers don't like chli with tomato chunks and this recipe fit the bill.  My  16 year old son said it was the "best chili he ever had." The flavor is excellent. If you like more tomato chunks just add canned tomatoes like everyone else did.  I followed the recipe exactly and did not find it to be too runny.  However I added 2 cans of kidney beans that probably added up to more than 2 cups as the recipe called for.  If you let the chili simmer the full hour and a half it simmers down to a thicker consistency. Next time I will make a double recipe however so I have more leftovers to freeze for another meal.

country:
None
text:
This chili is really good!  I followed the instructions almost completely.  Because I don't want to cry while chopping onions I omitted them and added some white mushrooms and some portebello mushrooms.  I think there's a few different types of chili mixes.  Considering that this recipe asks for 1/4 cups I picked the kind that was less spicy.  It didn't turn out that spicy but in my opinion 1/4 cups of chili powder is too much powder to be adding.  I simmered it for 2 hours and mixed it too but I still feel that the chili powder isn't that well blended into the mix.  Next time maybe I'll use less chili powder and add some hot sauce to it or use a little bit of the more spicy chili powder.
